item.title: O and A: Tolstoy, Bolshoi and krakadil Gena
item.description: Oh and ah The o is the most common letter in Russian (as mentioned in Paste Sounds ). Were all those o’s to have an o sound, the whole language would have changed sound. Now it has been determined that an unstressed o (usually) sounds like an a, and that was a good idea.

item.title: Mother of God on the Moat: St. Basil’s Cathedral
item.description: Ivan IV Built to commemorate the Conquest of Kazan on the orders of Ivan IV (1530-1584), better known as the Terrible or Грозный . While the name translates to “terrible,” it’s a bit exaggerated – as a character sketch, it’s still mild.

item.title: The letter ы
item.description: Sounds Like An indescribable sound, indeed. But people have tried. Wikipedia loosely describes it as “like the u in bunker” (which is far off). Wikibooks says it’s somewhere between “u” and “j”, while Russisch in Rusland compares it to something between “u” and “i”.
